rev.comment: rm one image that is a copyvio on commons, put infobox back where it usually goes, and TOC back where it usually goes, per discussion
rev.diff:
Line 1: Line 1:
{{Other uses}}
{{Other uses}}
â   â
'''Twiggy''' (born '''Lesley Hornby'''; 19 September 1949) is an [[English People|English]] [[model (person)|model]], actress, and singer, now also known by her married name of '''Twiggy Lawson'''. At 16, she became the first prominent teenage model. She was known for her [[androgynous]] looks, large eyes, long eyelashes, thin build, and short hair.<ref name=hbtwig /><ref>{{cite news|title=Twiggy's wrinkles|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/news/2005/nov/02/mainsection.commentanddebate2|date=2 November 2005|author=Roberts, Yvonne|work=The Guardian | location=London}}</ref> In 1966, she was named âThe Face of 1966â by the ''[[Daily Express]]''<ref name="twigofficialsite">{{cite web|url=http://www.twiggylawson.co.uk/biography.html |title=Twiggy - The Official Site |publisher=Twiggylawson.co.uk |date=1949-09-19 |accessdate=2010-05-01}}</ref> and voted British Woman of the Year.<ref name="twigbiochannel">{{cite web|url=http://www.thebiographychannel.co.uk/biographies/twiggy.html |title=Twiggy - Biography on Bio |publisher=Thebiographychannel.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2010-05-01}}</ref> By 1967, Twiggy had modelled in France, Japan, and the U.S., and landed on the covers of ''[[Vogue (magazine)|Vogue]]'' and ''[[Tatler|The Tatler]]''. Her fame had spread worldwide.<ref name="twigbiochannel" />
  â   â
After modelling, Twiggy went on to enjoy a successful career as a screen, stage, and television actress. She has hosted her own series, ''Twiggy's People'', in which she interviewed celebrities, and also appeared as a judge on the reality show ''[[America's Next Top Model]]''. Her 1998 autobiography, ''Twiggy in Black and White'', entered the bestseller lists.<ref name="twigofficialsite" /> Since 2005, she has modelled for [[Marks and Spencer]], most recently to promote their recent rebranding, appearing in TV adverts and print media, alongside [[Myleene Klass]], [[Erin O'Connor]], [[Lily Cole]] and others.<ref name="exclusive">{{cite news|author=Jane Gordon |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/home/you/article-1054306/Exclusive-Twiggy-interview-Being-grown-woman-doesnt-mean-look-beautiful-individual-different.html#ixzz0c7bnvjO7 |title=Exclusive Twiggy interview: 'Being a grown-up woman doesn't mean you can't look beautiful, individual and different' |publisher=Dailymail.co.uk |date=2008-09-14 |accessdate=2010-05-01 | location=London}}</ref>
  â   â
{| align="right"
  â
| __TOC__
  â
|}
  â
==Personal life==
  â
Twiggy Lawson was brought up in the northwest [[London]] suburb of [[Neasden]], the daughter of Helen (Nellie) Lydia Hornby (''nÃ©e'' Reeman), a factory worker for a printing firm, and William Norman Hornby, a master carpenter and joiner.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nationsmemorybank.com/editorial/fashion_article_3.html |title=Twiggy |publisher=Nations Memory Bank |date= |accessdate=2010-05-01}}</ref> Twiggyâs mother taught her to sew from a young age, and she used this talent to make her own clothing.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.inoutstar.com/news/Lesley-Hornby-aka-Twiggy-672.html |title=Lesley Hornby aka Twiggy Biography |publisher=Inout Star |date=2007-06-30 |accessdate=2010-05-01}}</ref> She attended the [[Queens Park Community School|Brondesbury and Kilburn High School]] in Salusbury Road, [[Kilburn, London|Kilburn]]. Twiggy is the youngest of three sisters. Shirley is 15 years older, and Vivien is seven years older.<ref name="exclusive" />
  â   â   â
Twiggy married American actor [[Michael Witney]] in 1977. They had one daughter, Carly, born in 1978. That marriage ended with his sudden death in 1983 from a [[myocardial infarction|heart attack]]. Twiggy met her second husband, [[Leigh Lawson]], in 1984.<ref name="twigofficialsite" /> In 1988 they worked on the film ''[[Madame Sousatzka]]'', and married that year in Sag Harbor, Long Island. Lawson adopted Twiggyâs daughter, Carly, who took on his surname. The couple resides in London.
  â   â
In her official site, she describes herself as being an ardent supporter of breast cancer research, animal welfare, and anti-fur campaigns.<ref name="twigofficialsite" />
  â   â
==Modelling career (1965-1970)==
  â
[[File:Twiggy promo.jpg|thumb|left|<center>Twiggy in 1967, at the height of her modelling career, showing the look that made her famous.</center>]]
  â
===1965â1967===
  â
Twiggy is best remembered as one of the first international supermodels and a fashion icon of the 1960s and 70s.<ref name="face66">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/programmes/breakfast/4725427.stm |title=The face of '66 |publisher=BBC News |date=2005-07-29 |accessdate=2010-05-01}}</ref> Her greatest influence is [[Jean Shrimpton]],<ref>{{cite web|author=AAP |url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/life-style/138961 |title=60s icon Twiggy offers fashion advice |publisher=Stuff.co.nz |date= |accessdate=2010-05-01}}</ref><ref name=dickinson>{{cite web|url=http://channels.isp.netscape.com/celebrity/hollywoodexclusive.jsp?feature=ce_hol_09212005 |title=Dickinson 1st Supermodel? Not! Says Twiggy |publisher=Channels.isp.netscape.com |date= |accessdate=2010-05-01}}</ref> whom Twiggy considers to be the world's first supermodel.<ref name=dickinson /> Twiggy has also been described as the successor to Jean Shrimpton.<ref name=hbtwig>[http://www.harpersbazaar.com/fashion/fashion-articles/famous-models-0409 Best Models of All Time: #7 Twiggy] ''Harper's Bazaar''.</ref><ref>{{cite journal|title=TV: Camera on Twiggy; Cinema Verite Technique Helps Exploit Visit of Model Most in Vogue|url=http://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=FB0E16F63C5C107B93CAAB178FD85F438685F9|work=The New York Times|author=Gould, Jack|date=1967-04-28}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|title=The Arrival of Twiggy|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=b1YEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA33&dq=successor+twiggy+shrimpton&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&as_brr=0&cd=1#v=onepage&q|work=Life|date=1967-02-03}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|title=Pin Thin, Leggy Twiggy Is Tops|url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1499&dat=19661124&id=sOAjAAAAIBAJ&sjid=2CcEAAAAIBAJ&pg=7231,1716337|date=1966-11-24|work=Milwaukee Journal}}</ref> In January 1966, young Lesley Hornby had her hair colored and cut short in Mayfair at The House of Leonard,<ref>{{cite web|author=sentimentalsusan |url=http://modsixties.5forum.net/susan-camp-editors-updates-f9/twiggy-leonard-of-london-hairdo-magazine-1967-t544.htm |title=Twiggy & Leonard of London ~ HairDo Magazine 1967 |publisher=Modsixties.5forum.net |date=2008-11-10 |accessdate=2010-05-01}}</ref> owned by celebrity hairdresser Leonard.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.twiggylawson.co.uk/fashion.html |title=Twiggy - The Official Site |publisher=Twiggylawson.co.uk |date=1966-02-23 |accessdate=2010-05-01}}</ref> The hair stylist was looking for models on whom to try out his new crop haircut and he styled her hair in preparation for a few test head shots.<ref name="twiggy60">{{cite news|author=Jess Cartner-Morley |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/lifeandstyle/2009/sep/19/twiggy-at-60-interview |title=Twiggy at 60: 'It's amazing I didn't go bonkers' |publisher=The Guardian |date= 2009-09-19|accessdate=2010-05-01 | location=London}}</ref> A professional photographer Barry Lategan took several photos for Leonard, which the hairdresser hung in his salon. Deidre McSharry, a fashion journalist from the ''[[Daily Express]]'', saw the images and asked to meet the young girl.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blog.fidmmuseum.org/museum/2009/11/twiggy-.html |title=Twiggy |publisher=FIDM Museum Blog|date=2009-11-02 |accessdate=2010-05-01}}</ref> McSharry arranged to have more photos taken. A few weeks later the publication featured an article and images of Hornby, declaring her âThe Face of â66.â<ref name="face66" /><ref name="portraitgallery">{{cite news|author=Maev Kennedy |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/lifeandstyle/2009/jul/08/twiggy-exhibition-national-portrait-gallery |title=Face of 2009: Gallery celebrates Twiggy's career |publisher=Guardian |date= 2009-07-08|accessdate=2010-05-01 | location=London}}</ref> In it, the copy read: "The Cockney Kid with a face to launch a thousand shapes ... and she's only 16! - ''The Daily Express'', 23 February 1966.
  â  
{{Infobox model
{{Infobox model
| name = Twiggy
| name = Twiggy

  +
'''Twiggy''' (born '''Lesley Hornby'''; 19 September 1949) is an [[English People|English]] [[model (person)|model]], actress, and singer, now also known by her married name of '''Twiggy Lawson'''. At 16, she became the first prominent teenage model. She was known for her [[androgynous]] looks, large eyes, long eyelashes, thin build, and short hair.<ref name=hbtwig /><ref>{{cite news|title=Twiggy's wrinkles|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/news/2005/nov/02/mainsection.commentanddebate2|date=2 November 2005|author=Roberts, Yvonne|work=The Guardian | location=London}}</ref> In 1966, she was named âThe Face of 1966â by the ''[[Daily Express]]''<ref name="twigofficialsite">{{cite web|url=http://www.twiggylawson.co.uk/biography.html |title=Twiggy - The Official Site |publisher=Twiggylawson.co.uk |date=1949-09-19 |accessdate=2010-05-01}}</ref> and voted British Woman of the Year.<ref name="twigbiochannel">{{cite web|url=http://www.thebiographychannel.co.uk/biographies/twiggy.html |title=Twiggy - Biography on Bio |publisher=Thebiographychannel.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2010-05-01}}</ref> By 1967, Twiggy had modelled in France, Japan, and the U.S., and landed on the covers of ''[[Vogue (magazine)|Vogue]]'' and ''[[Tatler|The Tatler]]''. Her fame had spread worldwide.<ref name="twigbiochannel" />
  +   +
After modelling, Twiggy went on to enjoy a successful career as a screen, stage, and television actress. She has hosted her own series, ''Twiggy's People'', in which she interviewed celebrities, and also appeared as a judge on the reality show ''[[America's Next Top Model]]''. Her 1998 autobiography, ''Twiggy in Black and White'', entered the bestseller lists.<ref name="twigofficialsite" /> Since 2005, she has modelled for [[Marks and Spencer]], most recently to promote their recent rebranding, appearing in TV adverts and print media, alongside [[Myleene Klass]], [[Erin O'Connor]], [[Lily Cole]] and others.<ref name="exclusive">{{cite news|author=Jane Gordon |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/home/you/article-1054306/Exclusive-Twiggy-interview-Being-grown-woman-doesnt-mean-look-beautiful-individual-different.html#ixzz0c7bnvjO7 |title=Exclusive Twiggy interview: 'Being a grown-up woman doesn't mean you can't look beautiful, individual and different' |publisher=Dailymail.co.uk |date=2008-09-14 |accessdate=2010-05-01 | location=London}}</ref>
  +
{{toc}}
  +
==Personal life==
  +
Twiggy Lawson was brought up in the northwest [[London]] suburb of [[Neasden]], the daughter of Helen (Nellie) Lydia Hornby (''nÃ©e'' Reeman), a factory worker for a printing firm, and William Norman Hornby, a master carpenter and joiner.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nationsmemorybank.com/editorial/fashion_article_3.html |title=Twiggy |publisher=Nations Memory Bank |date= |accessdate=2010-05-01}}</ref> Twiggyâs mother taught her to sew from a young age, and she used this talent to make her own clothing.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.inoutstar.com/news/Lesley-Hornby-aka-Twiggy-672.html |title=Lesley Hornby aka Twiggy Biography |publisher=Inout Star |date=2007-06-30 |accessdate=2010-05-01}}</ref> She attended the [[Queens Park Community School|Brondesbury and Kilburn High School]] in Salusbury Road, [[Kilburn, London|Kilburn]]. Twiggy is the youngest of three sisters. Shirley is 15 years older, and Vivien is seven years older.<ref name="exclusive" />
  +   +   +
Twiggy married American actor [[Michael Witney]] in 1977. They had one daughter, Carly, born in 1978. That marriage ended with his sudden death in 1983 from a [[myocardial infarction|heart attack]]. Twiggy met her second husband, [[Leigh Lawson]], in 1984.<ref name="twigofficialsite" /> In 1988 they worked on the film ''[[Madame Sousatzka]]'', and married that year in Sag Harbor, Long Island. Lawson adopted Twiggyâs daughter, Carly, who took on his surname. The couple resides in London.
  +   +
In her official site, she describes herself as being an ardent supporter of breast cancer research, animal welfare, and anti-fur campaigns.<ref name="twigofficialsite" />
  +   +
==Modelling career (1965-1970)==
  +
[[File:Twiggy promo.jpg|thumb|<center>Twiggy in 1967, at the height of her modelling career, showing the look that made her famous.</center>]]
  +
===1965â1967===
  +
Twiggy is best remembered as one of the first international supermodels and a fashion icon of the 1960s and 70s.<ref name="face66">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/programmes/breakfast/4725427.stm |title=The face of '66 |publisher=BBC News |date=2005-07-29 |accessdate=2010-05-01}}</ref> Her greatest influence is [[Jean Shrimpton]],<ref>{{cite web|author=AAP |url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/life-style/138961 |title=60s icon Twiggy offers fashion advice |publisher=Stuff.co.nz |date= |accessdate=2010-05-01}}</ref><ref name=dickinson>{{cite web|url=http://channels.isp.netscape.com/celebrity/hollywoodexclusive.jsp?feature=ce_hol_09212005 |title=Dickinson 1st Supermodel? Not! Says Twiggy |publisher=Channels.isp.netscape.com |date= |accessdate=2010-05-01}}</ref> whom Twiggy considers to be the world's first supermodel.<ref name=dickinson /> Twiggy has also been described as the successor to Jean Shrimpton.<ref name=hbtwig>[http://www.harpersbazaar.com/fashion/fashion-articles/famous-models-0409 Best Models of All Time: #7 Twiggy] ''Harper's Bazaar''.</ref><ref>{{cite journal|title=TV: Camera on Twiggy; Cinema Verite Technique Helps Exploit Visit of Model Most in Vogue|url=http://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=FB0E16F63C5C107B93CAAB178FD85F438685F9|work=The New York Times|author=Gould, Jack|date=1967-04-28}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|title=The Arrival of Twiggy|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=b1YEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA33&dq=successor+twiggy+shrimpton&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&as_brr=0&cd=1#v=onepage&q|work=Life|date=1967-02-03}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|title=Pin Thin, Leggy Twiggy Is Tops|url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1499&dat=19661124&id=sOAjAAAAIBAJ&sjid=2CcEAAAAIBAJ&pg=7231,1716337|date=1966-11-24|work=Milwaukee Journal}}</ref> In January 1966, young Lesley Hornby had her hair colored and cut short in Mayfair at The House of Leonard,<ref>{{cite web|author=sentimentalsusan |url=http://modsixties.5forum.net/susan-camp-editors-updates-f9/twiggy-leonard-of-london-hairdo-magazine-1967-t544.htm |title=Twiggy & Leonard of London ~ HairDo Magazine 1967 |publisher=Modsixties.5forum.net |date=2008-11-10 |accessdate=2010-05-01}}</ref> owned by celebrity hairdresser Leonard.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.twiggylawson.co.uk/fashion.html |title=Twiggy - The Official Site |publisher=Twiggylawson.co.uk |date=1966-02-23 |accessdate=2010-05-01}}</ref> The hair stylist was looking for models on whom to try out his new crop haircut and he styled her hair in preparation for a few test head shots.<ref name="twiggy60">{{cite news|author=Jess Cartner-Morley |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/lifeandstyle/2009/sep/19/twiggy-at-60-interview |title=Twiggy at 60: 'It's amazing I didn't go bonkers' |publisher=The Guardian |date= 2009-09-19|accessdate=2010-05-01 | location=London}}</ref> A professional photographer Barry Lategan took several photos for Leonard, which the hairdresser hung in his salon. Deidre McSharry, a fashion journalist from the ''[[Daily Express]]'', saw the images and asked to meet the young girl.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blog.fidmmuseum.org/museum/2009/11/twiggy-.html |title=Twiggy |publisher=FIDM Museum Blog|date=2009-11-02 |accessdate=2010-05-01}}</ref> McSharry arranged to have more photos taken. A few weeks later the publication featured an article and images of Hornby, declaring her âThe Face of â66.â<ref name="face66" /><ref name="portraitgallery">{{cite news|author=Maev Kennedy |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/lifeandstyle/2009/jul/08/twiggy-exhibition-national-portrait-gallery |title=Face of 2009: Gallery celebrates Twiggy's career |publisher=Guardian |date= 2009-07-08|accessdate=2010-05-01 | location=London}}</ref> In it, the copy read: "The Cockney Kid with a face to launch a thousand shapes ... and she's only 16! - ''The Daily Express'', 23 February 1966.
  +
Lesley's career quickly took off.<ref name="portraitgallery" /> She was 5'6" tall (short for a model), weighed a mere 6Â½ [[stone (Imperial mass)|stone]] (41 kg, 91 lbs) and had a 31-22-32 figure, "with a new kind of streamlined, androgynous sex appeal."<ref>{{cite news|author= Cheever, Susan|date= May 1983|url= http://www.nytimes.com/specials/magazine4/articles/twiggy.html|title= Twiggy|publisher= New York Times|accessdate= 2007-04-17 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20061109120757/http://www.nytimes.com/specials/magazine4/articles/twiggy.html <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 2006-11-09}}</ref> Her hairdresser boyfriend, Nigel Davies, became her manager, changed his name to [[Justin de Villeneuve]], and persuaded her to change her name to Twiggy (from âTwigsâ, her childhood nickname{{Citation needed|date=September 2010}}). De Villeneuve credits himself for Twiggyâs discovery and her modelling success, and his version of events is often quoted in other biographies.<ref name="twiggy60" /><ref name="summer">{{cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/theguardian/2006/aug/01/features11.g2 |title=Summer of hate |publisher=The Guardian |date=2006-08-01 |accessdate=2010-05-01 | location=London | first=Emine | last=Saner}}</ref> Ten years her senior, he managed her lucrative career for seven years, overseeing her finances and enterprises during her heyday as a model.
Lesley's career quickly took off.<ref name="portraitgallery" /> She was 5'6" tall (short for a model), weighed a mere 6Â½ [[stone (Imperial mass)|stone]] (41 kg, 91 lbs) and had a 31-22-32 figure, "with a new kind of streamlined, androgynous sex appeal."<ref>{{cite news|author= Cheever, Susan|date= May 1983|url= http://www.nytimes.com/specials/magazine4/articles/twiggy.html|title= Twiggy|publisher= New York Times|accessdate= 2007-04-17 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20061109120757/http://www.nytimes.com/specials/magazine4/articles/twiggy.html <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 2006-11-09}}</ref> Her hairdresser boyfriend, Nigel Davies, became her manager, changed his name to [[Justin de Villeneuve]], and persuaded her to change her name to Twiggy (from âTwigsâ, her childhood nickname{{Citation needed|date=September 2010}}). De Villeneuve credits himself for Twiggyâs discovery and her modelling success, and his version of events is often quoted in other biographies.<ref name="twiggy60" /><ref name="summer">{{cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/theguardian/2006/aug/01/features11.g2 |title=Summer of hate |publisher=The Guardian |date=2006-08-01 |accessdate=2010-05-01 | location=London | first=Emine | last=Saner}}</ref> Ten years her senior, he managed her lucrative career for seven years, overseeing her finances and enterprises during her heyday as a model.
Line 52: Line 48:
===1967â1970===
===1967â1970===
â
[[File:Olivetti Henry Wolf.jpg|thumb|left|<center>Twiggy in a typewriter ad. Photo by Henry Wolf.</center>]]
 
Twiggy arrived in New York in March 1967 at [[John F. Kennedy International Airport|JFK airport]], an event covered by the press.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hl-8Pej7bHo&feature=related |title=Twiggy Press Conference |publisher=YouTube |date=2008-04-23 |accessdate=2010-05-01}}</ref> ''[[The New Yorker]]'', ''[[Life (magazine)|Life]]'' and ''[[Newsweek]]'' reported on the Twiggy "phenomenon" in 1967, with the ''New Yorker'' devoting nearly 100 pages to the subject."<ref name="twiggy60" /> That year she became an international sensation, modeling in France, Japan, and America,<ref name="twigbiochannel" /> and landing the cover of Paris ''Vogue'' in May,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://hauteworld.blogspot.com/2009/10/vogue-covers-1920-2009-paris-france.html |title=Vogue Covers 1920-2009 (Paris, France)|publisher=Hauteworld.blogspot.com |date= |accessdate=2010-05-01}}</ref> the cover of US ''Vogue'' three times, in April, July and November, and the cover of British ''Vogue'' in October.<ref name="eyelashes" /> In 1967, an editorial on p. 63 of the March 15 edition of ''Vogue'' described her as an "extravaganza that makes the look of the sixties."
Twiggy arrived in New York in March 1967 at [[John F. Kennedy International Airport|JFK airport]], an event covered by the press.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hl-8Pej7bHo&feature=related |title=Twiggy Press Conference |publisher=YouTube |date=2008-04-23 |accessdate=2010-05-01}}</ref> ''[[The New Yorker]]'', ''[[Life (magazine)|Life]]'' and ''[[Newsweek]]'' reported on the Twiggy "phenomenon" in 1967, with the ''New Yorker'' devoting nearly 100 pages to the subject."<ref name="twiggy60" /> That year she became an international sensation, modeling in France, Japan, and America,<ref name="twigbiochannel" /> and landing the cover of Paris ''Vogue'' in May,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://hauteworld.blogspot.com/2009/10/vogue-covers-1920-2009-paris-france.html |title=Vogue Covers 1920-2009 (Paris, France)|publisher=Hauteworld.blogspot.com |date= |accessdate=2010-05-01}}</ref> the cover of US ''Vogue'' three times, in April, July and November, and the cover of British ''Vogue'' in October.<ref name="eyelashes" /> In 1967, an editorial on p. 63 of the March 15 edition of ''Vogue'' described her as an "extravaganza that makes the look of the sixties."
